column1: Â "The university has the responsibility to ensure that they are not over-invested in their work by creating a duty for the university to provide services to their students.
In the absence of such a duty, the university should not be able to create an additional duty to the extent that it is not able to fulfil the duty.
The university is concerned about the potential for a "social engineering" of some of its staff.

The university claims that it is "not able to offer services to students in a manner that is appropriate for their own academic and practical needs" and that it has had "more than one case of an employee who was not able to satisfactorily complete the required coursework in the required areas".
It is also concerned about the possibility of students being forced to perform "work of some kind" that is part of the university's responsibilities.
It notes that for example it cannot provide services without prior approval from the University Registrar, the Registrar of College, or the university's ethics committee.
The university also says it does not provide "any new or improved services".
The policy is also criticised for being "a thinly disguised attempt to protect the interests of the university, its students and staff".
The university has taken a number of steps to protect its reputation and reputation as a leading institution in the world and I think it's a good thing we're doing this very well, said the policy.

We're also investing in the way we do things, so we're not trying to make a big deal of it, in the sense that we're not trying to make a big deal of it.

We've had some of the most successful campaigns in this country in terms of the quality of the service we provide and the quality of our staff. We also've had a number of other initiatives to improve the quality of our staff.
The university has now taken a number of steps to protect its reputation and reputation as a leading institution in the world and I think it's a good thing we're doing this very well.
